bibl.title: Letter from Harry Clemons to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 19, 1947

div1.p: Clemons relates a talk by Hench where Kean was enthusiastically mentioned many times. Clemons is trying to get Hench to donate his Reed Collection to the University of Virginia instead of the Mayo Clinic. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Harry Clemons to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 19, 1947
div1.p:
If your system of what somebody -- perhaps
it was Mark Twain -- called ‘mental telegraphy’ was in operation
Monday afternoon from four thirty to five forty-five, the results
must have been warming. For Dr. Philip Hench was addressing a
group of about one hundred and fifty persons (including President
Darden, Dean Jordan, and representatives from the Charlottesville
community and the Alderman Library) in the amphitheatre of the
University Hospital on details of his investigations concerning
Walter Reed and Yellow Fever. It was an address which commanded
attention as completely as did your address and that of the
surprised Sergeant Moran on a famous occasion several years ago.
The wires to 2804 N Street must have been warm because you were
not only mentioned a score of times but you were pointed out in
several pictures which were projected on a screen -- including a
delightful individual photograph of Major Kean. The address was
received with notable enthusiasm.

Doctor Hench had lent to the Alderman Library a number
of the documents of his collection, and those with a selection
from the material which you so generously donated are now on
exhibition in the Library. We are angling for Doctor Hench's
collection. But it seems that he has placed the Mayo Hospital
before the University of Virginia on his list of possible loca-
tions, and that our chance depends largely on a possible dis-
inclination of the Mayo Hospital authorities to begin a policy
of adding historical collections. Doctor Hench states that so
far the tendency at Rochester has been to concentrate on point-
ing forward and not backward.

Your very fine letter of November twelfth has been
read and reread, and it is being held out for reading by Emily
and George Vest when they are here this coming weekend. The
good counsel about matters of living in Bermuda is most timely,
for they are scheduled to start thither by plane next week --
about November twenty-eighth. They have recently been in New
York to study shipping matters as a part of the indoctrination
course -- and have incidentally been attending one or two of
the meetings of the United Nations.

I am concerned that you have been troubled by a chance
disappearance of the recent issue of The Military Surgeon.
You are so generous in donating your personal copies that you
must not let such generosity inject such anxieties. One thing
on which we are really authorities here is on the tendency of
periodicals and books to slip into hiding and occasionally to
achieve a complete disappearance. So we hope you will remember
that we should much prefer to arrange here for the replacement
of a missing copy than to have you bothered by an incident
like this.

It has embarrassed me no little that a copy of the
recent Virginia Spectator has fallen into your hands. That
write-up and an astonishing editorial which Mr. Virginius
Dabney wrote for the Richmond Times-Dispatch one day last
August have produced in me a strange mixture of surprise, con-
fusion, and gratification. It is certainly unusual for the
humdrum work of a librarian (and his Van Dyke beard) to be
given such notice. I do not forget that the surprising attitude
of this university community was the initial cause of one of the
very pleasantest chapters of my librarian life. For it was the
chance juxtaposition of a Raven Society election to you and of
a Raven award to me that started our acquaintance one fair eve-
ning when we sat together at the head table of a Raven banquet
at the Farmington Country Club.
div1.closer:
Cordially yours, Harry Clemons Librarian
To General Jefferson R. Kean
2804 N Street, N.W.
Washington (7), D. C.
